Common Utilities¶

Surrogate Model Tools¶

Decision Tree Surrogate¶

class Common.DecisionTreeSurrogate.DecisionTreeSurrogate.DecisionTreeSurrogate(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, regressorFile=None)[source]¶
__init__(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, regressorFile=None)[source]¶

Constructor for DecisionTreeSurrogate, which wraps the scikit-learn RandomForestRegressor class. This class generates many dicision trees with random configurations to avoid overfitting the model to the training data.

Parameters:
  • trainingFile – String location of the training CSV file, which must include column headers
  • inputCols – List of strings corresponding to the input column names
  • outputCols – List of strings corresponding to the output column names
  • regressorFile – (optional) String location of trained and pickled model. This is saved on training completion.
Returns:

Initialized DecisionTreeSurrogate object
print_sim(inValues)[source]¶

A simple method that wil print out the value of the array, inValues, with the corresponding output value. This is primarily used for quickly testing to see how well the trained surrogate works.

Parameters:inValues – Array or list of input values to retrieve and print out output values for
Returns:None, prints to console
sim(inValue)[source]¶

Executes the trained surrogate model on new input data.

Parameters:inValue – An array or list of values with the same length of the list of input columns (inputCols)
Returns:An array of values with the same length of the list of output columns (outputCols)
test()[source]¶

Executes the testing of the model with the scipy linregress() function. This prints out the results for each output to the console.

Returns:None, prints to console
train(n_estimators)[source]¶

Trains the surrogate model with the initialized input and output data, given the number of estimators to use. This is used as an input to the RandomForestRegressor initializer, and controls the number of decision trees created by the random forest tree.

Parameters:n_estimators – number of decision trees for training, :note: can increase run time
Returns:None

Neural Network (Ffnet) Surrogate¶

class Common.FfnetSurrogate.FfnetSurrogate.FfnetSurrogate(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, netFile=None, multi=False)[source]¶
__init__(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, netFile=None, multi=False)[source]¶

Constructor for FfnetSurrogate, which wraps the ffnet ffnet class. This class is a feed-forward neural network library written in Fortran, that is wrapped with a python interface. The way this differs from the neurolab newff feed-forward network class, is that it can make use of multiple processors for training, and typically produces better results.

There is an existing plugin for OpenMDAO wrapping this library, but using it involves actually having the real model connected into OpenMDAO for training. This class provides the ability to just have a csv file of results, so that you can generate the surrogate ahead of time, then just use it by loading the saved model.

Parameters:
  • trainingFile – String location of the training CSV file, which must include column headers
  • inputCols – List of strings corresponding to the input column names
  • outputCols – List of strings corresponding to the output column names
  • regressorFile – (optional) String location of trained and saved network. This is saved on training completion.
Returns:

Initialized FfnetSurrogate object
print_sim(inValues)[source]¶

A simple method that wil print out the value of the array, inValues, with the corresponding output value. This is primarily used for quickly testing to see how well the trained surrogate works.

Parameters:inValues – Array or list of input values to retrieve and print out output values for
Returns:None, prints to console
sim(inValue)[source]¶

Executes the trained surrogate model on new input data.

Parameters:inValue – An array or list of values with the same length of the list of input columns (inputCols)
Returns:An array of values with the same length of the list of output columns (outputCols)
test()[source]¶

Executes the testing of the model with the scipy linregress() function. This prints out the results for each output to the console.

Returns:None, prints to console
train(num_neurons)[source]¶

Creates a network topology from the num_neurons input, then trains the surrogate model with the initialized input and output data. The network topology is used as an input to the ffnet initializer.

Parameters:num_neurons – number of internal neurons :note: this can help create a better fit for a complicated model, at the expense of requiring more computational resources to train.
Returns:None, saves network to disk as ffnetSurrogate.net

Neural Network (Neurolab) Surrogate¶

class Common.NeurolabSurrogate.NeurolabSurrogate.NeurolabSurrogate(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, netFile=None)[source]¶
__init__(trainingFile, inputCols, outputCols, netFile=None)[source]¶

Constructor for NeuroSurrogate, which wraps the neurolab newff class. This class is a feed-forward neural network library written in python. The way this differs from the ffnet ffnet feed-forward network library, is that it provides many more types of neural networks beyond just the feed-forward case, including newp, newc, newlvq, newelm, newhop, and newhem. Currently, only support for the newff is supported, but it could easily be extended to those as well.

Parameters:
  • trainingFile – String location of the training CSV file, which must include column headers
  • inputCols – List of strings corresponding to the input column names
  • outputCols – List of strings corresponding to the output column names
  • netFile – (optional) String location of trained and saved network. This is saved on training completion.
Returns:

Initialized NeurolabSurrogate object
create_norm_func()[source]¶

Neurolab requires that the output data be normalized ahead of time by the user. This can be difficult to deal with and makes the library hard to use. This method automates the process of getting the data into the correct format then generating a reusable function to convert the data back into the original format after you get outputs from the model on calling the sim method.

Returns:normalization function
print_sim(inValues)[source]¶

A simple method that wil print out the value of the array, inValues, with the corresponding output value. This is primarily used for quickly testing to see how well the trained surrogate works.

Parameters:inValues – Array or list of input values to retrieve and print out output values for
Returns:None, prints to console
sim(inValue)[source]¶

Executes the trained surrogate model on new input data.

Parameters:inValue – An array or list of values with the same length of the list of input columns (inputCols)
Returns:An array of values with the same length of the list of output columns (outputCols)
test()[source]¶

Executes the testing of the model with the scipy linregress() function. This prints out the results for each output to the console.

Returns:None, prints to console
train(num_neurons)[source]¶

Creates a network topology from the num_neurons input, then trains the surrogate model with the initialized input and output data. The network topology is used as an input to the newff(), which returns a Net object.

Parameters:num_neurons – number of internal neurons :note: this can help create a better fit for a complicated model, at the expense of requiring more computational resources to train.
Returns:None, saves network to disk as neurolabSurrogate.net

Helper Utilities¶

Common.AttributeTools.io.get_outputs(component)[source]¶

Retrieves the user-defined outputs from an OpenMDAO component.

Parameters:component – Initialized OpenMDAO component
Returns:Pure list of only user-defined outputs as strings
Common.AttributeTools.io.print_outputs(component)[source]¶

Prints only the user-defined outputs from an OpenMDAO component

Parameters:component – Initialized OpenMDAO component
Returns:None, prints to console
Common.AttributeTools.io.get_output_values(component)[source]¶

Retrieves the user-defined outputs form an OpenMDAO component and stores them into a python dict. It could be used as followed:

comp = MyComponent()
outputs = get_output_values(comp)
for output in outputs:
    this_value = outputs[output]
    do_something_with_value(this_value)
Parameters:component – Initialized OpenMDAO component
Returns:Python dict with keys of the output parameter names, with associated values
Common.AttributeTools.io.get_inputs(component)[source]¶

Retrieves the user-defined inputs from an OpenMDAO component as a list of strings. This is required since retrieving them directly from the component will include other attributes that were not defined by the user.

Parameters:component – Initialized OpenMDAO component
Returns:Pure list of only user-defined inputs as strings
Common.AttributeTools.io.get_input_values(component)[source]¶

Retrieves the user-defined inputs form an OpenMDAO component and stores them into a python dict. It could be used as followed:

comp = MyComponent()
inputs = get_input_values(comp)
for input in inputs:
    this_value = inputs[input]
    do_something_with_value(this_value)
Parameters:component – Initialized OpenMDAO component
Returns:Python dict with keys of the input parameter names, with associated values
